name: Specialist Expanding
description: Apply your existing expertise to a new domain - skip basics, focus on domain-specific differences
objectives: Transfer existing process knowledge to new domain
Understand unique security and compliance requirements
Build on existing expertise rather than starting from scratch
prerequisites: Strong expertise in at least one development domain

domain_customization.note: This path is customized based on source and target domains

milestones.name: Domain Context
milestones.description: Understand unique aspects of new domain

steps.why: Understand how users interact with systems in this domain
Learn domain-specific security threats (e.g., mobile: device security, ML: model poisoning)
Understand which patterns work in this domain and why
If moving to frontend: SPA vs MPA, state management, component patterns
Each domain has different performance characteristics and constraints

milestones.name: Domain-Specific Development
milestones.description: Learn coding patterns and tools for new domain

steps.why: OWASP Top 10 differs by domain (web vs mobile vs API vs ML)
Idiomatic code patterns vary by domain and language ecosystem
Testing strategies differ: UI testing vs API testing vs ML model testing
If moving to frontend/mobile: WCAG compliance and screen reader support
Mobile: app store submission, Web: CDN strategies, ML: model serving
What to monitor varies: API latency vs UI performance vs model drift

completion_criteria: Can identify domain-specific patterns vs universal principles
Understands unique security and compliance requirements
Knows which existing knowledge transfers and what's domain-specific
Can work effectively in new domain with appropriate patterns
next_steps: Deep dive into domain-specific examples in /examples/domain-specific/
Build a small project in new domain applying learned patterns
Consider Generalist Leveling Up for systematic coverage of gaps

backend_to_frontend: Focus on: Frontend architecture, state management, accessibility
Skip: Most testing fundamentals (you know them), basic security (apply to frontend context)
web_to_mobile: Focus on: Platform security models, offline-first, native vs cross-platform
Skip: Most architecture patterns (similar), deployment concepts (adapt to app stores)
traditional_to_ml: Focus on: Data pipelines, model training/deployment, ML-specific testing
Skip: Basic software engineering (you know it), apply to data context
